Should be sacked without question.Douglas McVey said: ldquoHe was wrong, thatrsquos the bottom line, no use trying to defend the man with all the fatherrsquos instinct nonsense. He made the mistake and was caught out while us mere mrtals are all doing the right thing.Susan Neil said: ldquo We lost our dad in March and told we canrsquot be with my mum to comfort her yet this p***k travels  plus miles for a babysitter.Stephen Miller said: ldquoHe probably has the cheek to clap every Thursday for key workers.Gordon Birnie said: ldquoDominic Cummings is giving Hans Christian Andersen a run for his money.ldquoForget about the  miles he drove to Durham from London, itrsquos the reason he gave for  mile trip to Castle Barnard he took.ldquoHe says it was lsquoto test his eyesight to seeit was good enough to driversquo so he drove  miles, decided his eyesight wasnrsquot good enough to drive the  miles back to London so he drove  back to Durham.

title: easter-ross-helen-sedgwick-tarbat-peninsula
story: Where is it The Tarbat Ness headland on the Tarbat peninsula, Easter Ross.Why do you go there Its a short drive from my house and it is the place I turn to when Im searching for inspiration, struggling to write, stressed, happy, restless or overwhelmed.The drive takes me past green fields and clusters of pretty houses, with panoramic views of long sandy beaches. Then the road narrows and I follow the single grey track to the lighthouse.The weather always turns at this point: the wind picks up, the landscape becomes dominated by the deep, glistening grey blues of the sea, the jagged blacks and browns of the rocks, the thorned yellow of gorse, and the distinctive red and white stripes of the lighthouse. The rest of the world fades away.How often do you go As often as I need to ndash Ive been known to visit on a daily basis. Its part of the rhythm of my le, which with a three-year-old can be unpredictable, butIve not been for a while, I long to go back, and I never tire of it.How did you discover it I had no idea it was there before I moved to the area. I saw a sign on one of my first visits to Portmahomack, followed the track to the lighthouse and found myself facing the most breathtaking view, surrounded by the sea in almost every direction.Author Helen Sedgwick. Picture: Michael GallacherI clambered over the rocks until I was at the furthest point of the land. The wind was wild and the waves were crashing against the rocks. I thought: "This is the place."Whats your favourite memory There are so many its hard to choose, and every time is dferent. One that stands out is the first time I saw a whole pod of dolphins playing along the coast that was magical.Who do you take My partner, our daughter, and any visitors we have.What do you take If Im going on my own, a notebook and pen. Its a place that inspires ideas and compels me to write. A camera or binocularsI want to watch for the dolphins. And always a woolly hat because its never not windy and the wind has bite.What do you leave behind Whatever is in my way. The landscape reminds me of how small we are, and how vast the world is in comparison. Whatever was worrying me seems unimportant when I can watch entire weather fronts moving across the sea. Its liberating.:Outlander stars Sam Heughan and Graham McTavish share their epic Scottish road tripSum it up in five words.Vast. Jagged. Windswept. Ancient. Inspiring.What travel spot is on your post-lockdown wish list The same asmy pre-lockdown wish list: Antarctica. Im not sureIll ever get there. But the wildness and expanse of Tarbat Ness, particularly during a storm, is a pretty impressive substitute.When The Dead Come Calling by Helen Sedgwick is published in paperback by Point Blank on Thursday, priced pound.

title: men-kilts-outlander-stars-sam-heughan-graham-mctavish
story: The Outlander stars are a likeable double act. Think Ant and Dec. A dash of The Two Ronnies. The s sitcom George and Mildred springs to mind briefly ndash perhaps because in one episode Heughan and McTavish end up haring about in a vintage motorcycle and sidecar.Across the eight-part series, the duo goes in search of places steeped in history and lore. The idea was sparked by McTavishrsquos love of clan heritage, something that Heughan equally became fascinated with while making Outlander, a time-travelling drama set in th-century Scotland.Heughan describes Men In Kilts as ldquoa love letter to Scotland, while McTavish bills it as ldquothe trip of a letime. Their enthusiasm is infectious as they delve into everything from langoustine fishing and the art of making whisky to witchcraft, ancient rituals and standing stones.Sweeping landscapes and dramatic aerial shots abound, but the best bits are when McTavish and Heughan are trundling along in their trusty campervan exchanging witty banter and mock barbs.Graham McTavish and Sam Heughan go langoustine fishing during their Scottish road trip for the TV series Men In Kilts. Picture: Robert Wilson StarzIt takes mere seconds for our interview to descend into this territory as I innocently enquire where they each are this fine evening. McTavish, , proffers an apologetic grin as Heughan, , pretends to act suspicious about his co-starrsquos whereabouts.Graham McTavish: ldquoI am in England.Sam Heughan: ldquoIn an undisclosed location.McTavish: ldquoI canrsquot talk about where I am because it would give away what I am doing.Heughan: ldquoHe doesnrsquot want to tell anyone, otherwise I would find him and make him do more Men In Kilts.McTavish: ldquoI am in a safe house. Secret undisclosed location. To keep me away from Heughan.Heughan: ldquoI thought as much.It has since been confirmed that McTavish, who played Dougal MacKenzie in Outlander and Dwalin in The Hobbit movie trilogy, has joined HBOrsquos upcoming Game of Thrones prequel, House of the Dragon, with filming under way in Cornwall.Heughan, meanwhile, is in Scotland shooting the sixth series of Outlander, the big-budget historical drama that launched his career around the globe thanks to a starring role as dashing Highlander Jamie Fraser.Men In Kilts is a markedly dferent project. Glasgow-born McTavish and Heughan, who is originally from Balmaclellan in Galloway and spent his teenage years in Edinburgh, hit the road last summer after the first lockdown lted.:Cat Deeley talks on-air disasters, romantic gestures and her new Scottish-made knitwear rangeThe pair published an accompanying book, Clanlands, in November. The TV series was shown in the US earlier this year and has newly begun airing on this side of the Atlantic, available via the on-demand streaming service StarzPlay.Each half-hour episode centres on a theme, journeying through food and drink, sport, song and dance, witchcraft and superstition, Scotland by land, air and sea, as well as tradition, clans and tartans, and the Battle of Culloden.The end result is proper feel-good telly. Fans of the funny, le-affirming Mortimer  Whitehouse: Gone Fishing will find Men In Kilts similarly entertaining viewing ndash it is in that same rich vein of two good friends enjoying a shared pilgrimage and zest for adventure.It is an odyssey fuelled by lashings of caffeine, good humour, adrenalin, drams of whisky, and apparently, in Heughanrsquos case, a desire to devise increasingly fiendish methods to terry McTavish .Coming up with the itinerary, they admit, was a tricky business. ldquoWe had to narrow it down because we wanted to go to loads of places, says McTavish. ldquoWe had to be realistic about where we could actually go. There were logistical factors involved.ldquoGiven the fact that we did manage to get across to Lewis and Islay and go up to Inverness, it was an extraordinarily circuitous journey. We based it on things that we were interested in.Sam Heughan and Graham McTavish at Clava Cairns near Inverness during their Scottish road trip for the TV series Men In Kilts. Picture: Peter Sandground StarzHeughan takes up the thread. ldquoWe were originally basing it on certain clans, he explains. ldquoThen we came up with a theme idea, didnrsquot we  We looked at where we would base ourselves and where we had always wanted to go ndash our bucket list of Scotland.ldquoIt is the bucket list of myself and McTavish. Places we can eat, places we can drink hellip McTavish starts laughing as Heughan reels off their criteria. ldquohellip Places we can learn about history and places I can throw him off a clf.McTavish chimes in. ldquoIslay was definitely always on the itinerary because Sam was very insistent. There were possibly two things you were insistent about: the Islay distillery and the surfing [on Lewis]. You were very enthusiastic about the surfing.The series is aimed predominantly at a US audience ndash co-produced by Sony Pictures Television which makes Outlander for Starz ndash but there are subtle cultural references woven throughout that will give many Scots a good chuckle.How did they go about striking a balance between trying to entertain and impart knowledge, in the first instance, to viewers who may not know Scotland all that well, while ensuring that the programme didnrsquot potentially jar with those watching on these shores ldquoThe way we approached it was to be as spontaneous and organic as possible, says McTavish. ldquoWe certainly didnrsquot want to come across as lecturing anybody about the history and landscape and world of Scotland. It was driven by our own enthusiasm for all of the places and people we encountered.ldquoWith the audience, as long as they feel that theyrsquore with us, as part of the journey, then our job was done. What we wanted to impart,anything, was the sense of us all going together and discovering all this stuff.:Outlander star Sam Heughan shares his favourite place in ScotlandHeughan agrees with this summary. ldquoBecause of lockdown and travel restrictions, people have started to rediscover this beautul country, he says. ldquoWe were among the first people to shoot in Scotland after the first lockdown.ldquoIt came out of us having almost a love letter to Scotland. We wanted to share it with the rest of the world. I hope when people in the UK watch it as well, they realise what is on their doorstep.The timing of Men In Kilts is serendipitous. As restrictions ease further and many Scots contemplate a summer break on home turf, it offers plenty of inspiration. If Heughan and McTavish could go anywhere right now ndash with no work ties or commitments ndash where would it be and why ldquoSomewhere I would love to go and have never been is the Applecross peninsula, says McTavish. ldquoAt one point we were thinking of cycling up that hill [Bealach na Ba]. It is part of the North Coast . Maybe one day we will. I have always wanted to go there.How about Heughan  ldquoI have a great love of getting on ferries, he says. ldquoThere was a point where we did build up a schedule for going to visit the smaller islands.ldquoSome of the Inner Hebrides ndash Eigg, Muck and Mull, I think Rum ndash we were going to do. But then with timing and the schedule it didnrsquot happen. There is something very magical about the wildle and the history. That is somewhere I would love to be, especially with good weather.Sam Heughan and Graham McTavish at Borthwick Castle near Edinburgh during their Scottish road trip for the TV series Men In Kilts. Picture: Robert Wilson StarzThe duo is rarely without a mischievous twinkle in their eyes. They share a similar sense of humour and seldom go more than a few moments without some light-hearted teasing. How would Heughan and McTavish describe each other ndash in only a few words ndash as travelling companions McTavish swtly passes the buck. ldquoYou go first, Sam, he coaxes. Heughan looks pensive. ldquoI can guess what his would be, he says. ldquoIt will be something like: lsquoA pain in the a***.rsquoHis co-star gasps in horror. ldquoNo! Not at all, insists McTavish. ldquoI would never describe you as a pain in the a***. Feel free to describe me as that. But you are not a pain in the a***.Heughan mulls over his reply: ldquoI was going to say something like lsquogood clean funrsquo. But really, there is nothing clean about Graham McTavishrsquos humour. I would say: lsquoA dirty good time.rsquoMcTavish: ldquoIf you are wanting a dirty good time hellipHeughan: ldquohellip call McTavish. McTavish Holidays: A Dirty Good Time.McTavish: ldquoWell, yours would be: lsquoAn unpredictable, bowel-loosening time.rsquoHeughan: ldquoOh, lovely.They are grinning now. Testament to the latter description are McTavishrsquos not-so-subtle gripes about Heughanrsquos driving, coupled with Heughanrsquos love of high-octane pursuits and a knack for making McTavish jump out his skin when visiting spooky locations.:Outlander star Graham McTavish on a Hebridean adventure fromBarra to LewisThroughout the series, the pair utilise several modes of transportation ndash everything from a rowing boat to a tandem bicycle. Did they have a favourite steed ldquoThe campervan for me, says McTavish. ldquoIt was the most comfortable. It had heat. You werenrsquot getting blasted [by the elements], and your backside wasnrsquot being ruined by a piece of ironmongery that masqueraded as a bike.Heughan lays his cards on the table. ldquoTo be honest, the real premise of the show was for me to try find ways to put Graham McTavish in uncomfortable situations and I did try to find other means of transport and other ridiculous things to make him do.ldquoHe did refuse point blank to do some. There are things I made him do that he then regretted. Well, maybe not regret hellip McTavish interjects. ldquoNo, I regretted them, he deadpans.Therersquos one thing they do agree on: a love of the amber nectar. Heughan is a bona fide connoisseur who has launched an award-winning blended Scotch whisky, The Sassenach, while McTavish ndash by his own admission ndash is more of a bluffer, confessing to faking his expertise over the years.Sam Heughan and Graham McTavish learned how to cut peat at the Laphroaig distillery on Islay while filming Men In Kilts. Picture: Robert Wilson StarzMen In Kilts saw them visit the Laphroaig distillery on Islay where they were given a masterclass in cutting peat, got to e headfirst into a malted barley store and ndash surprise, surprise ndash enjoy a few drams. What  did they learn ldquoI learned of Samrsquos ability to hide whisky all about his person, says McTavish. ldquoI have no idea how he managed it sometimes. I think he actually had some in his wetsuit when we were surfing. It was just incredible how you managed to secrete it.Heughan plays along. ldquoIt was to keep me warm, he says. ldquoYou pour it down the wetsuit. It keeps you warm. Saves you peeing yourself.McTavish doesnrsquot even bat an eyelid at that last quip. ldquoWhatever the situation, Sam would be able to celebrate it with a dram, he attests. ldquoThat was always quite lovely for him to surprise me with. He would just suddenly pop out a flask.Heughan, meanwhile, is clearly in his happy place talking about whisky. ldquoIt is such a strong part of Scottish heritage and culture, he says. ldquoThat was interesting to dig into. Even going back to the historical side with the illicit stills. It is synonymous with Scotland, so why not celebrate it Something I am keen to ask them about is the notion of ldquoScottish cringe, a term used to describe embarrassment at overt expressions of national pride or cultural identity. It is a construct best captured by Rentonrsquos infamous ldquoit is s**** being Scottish speech in the  film Trainspotting.Graham McTavish and Sam Heughan at Cawdor Castle during their Scottish road trip for the TV series Men In Kilts. Picture: Peter Sandground StarzIn recent years, it has been suggested that Scottish cringe could be diminishing. Is that something they have experienced ldquoI think you are right, says McTavish. ldquoThere has been a change. Now, being from Scotland is something not to hide. Certainly, for my fatherrsquos generation, it was hard. You were often the butt of jokesyou were from Scotland. But not anymore.Heughan is in fervent agreement. ldquoAbsolutely. I think it is the reason I wanted to make the show, he says. ldquoSomething I noticed working on Outlander was obviously this huge lsquoOutlander effectrsquo of people being interested in Scotland and Scottish history.ldquoI remember when I was growing up there was [this idea of] a very dour Scotsman. It was dreich and dark, and we Scottish people put ourselves down ndash or used to.ldquoThere is this new positivity and, dare I say, itrsquos because of a strong identity and because we are a great little country and we have so much to celebrate. We are showing other parts of the UK how things should be done, maybe. It is certainly interesting.Over the series, they cover a lot of ground. Culloden, though, gets a big standalone episode to itself. This, says McTavish and Heughan, was something they felt passionately about.ldquoIt is a pivotal moment, not just in Scottish history but British history and arguably world history, says McTavish. ldquoYou see the ramications of Culloden. Certainly, for the Highland culture and what that then did to Scotland ndash good or bad ndash is undeniable.Graham McTavish and Sam Heughan enjoy a dram beside their campervan while filming the TV series Men In Kilts. Picture: Robert Wilson Starz"We were lucky enough to have some fabulous people to talk to about it, such as [the author and historian] Alistair Moffat. Going to Culloden and having Iain MacGillivray play the pipes on the battlefield ndash those were standout moments for me.Heughan says they wanted to challenge some of the myths about the Culloden story. ldquoIt is a battle that most Scottish people have heard about, but they probably think the Scots got beaten by lsquothe Englishrsquo or the British, he says.ldquoAs Graham says, it was this huge pivotal moment that had repercussions all around the world. It is a fascinating story and one we wanted to tell.McTavish is warming to his subject. ldquoI think as well that Culloden represents somewhat of the distillation of the myth and romanticism of Scotland, which I was interested in exploring, he continues.ldquoBecause when Sam says the Scots and lsquothe Englishrsquo in inverted commas, of course, the reality was not that at all. It was Scots against Scots.ldquoThere were more Scots on the British side than there were on the Jacobite side. So, it is important, when you look at history, that you look at it and see what really happened ndash not just what you would like to have happened."That is something I think that we both learned about. Not just with Culloden but generally doing the show.:Cat Deeley talks on-air disasters, romantic gestures and her new Scottish-made knitwear rangeIt is almost time to wrap up our conversation. They evidently had a blast filming Men In Kilts. Would they do a second series  ldquoDefinitely. Love to, says McTavish, answering without hesitation.Heughan echoes this sentiment. Well, at least, I think he does ... ldquoThere are plans afoot, he declares.ldquoThe campervan is being renovated right now. We are putting in some roll bars, safety devices, a larger toilet and a kitchen. Hopefully, it will be ready to go.Men In Kilts: A Roadtrip with Sam and Graham is available on StarzPlay now

title: walk-beinn-maol-chaluim-corbett-secretive-seductive
story: The walk: Beinn Maol Chaluim, this Corbett is secretive and seductiveWild scenery is guaranteed from Beinn Maol ChaluimGrade: Moderate hill walkDistance:  miles kmTime: - hoursHIDDEN away in a cleft of wild mountainous land between Glen Coe and Glen Etive, the Corbett of Beinn Maol Chaluim, ft m, does not attract large numbers of hillwalkers.Its proximity to the popular Munros of Glen Coe tends to keep it relatively free of people. Those hillwalkers who do take the long single-track road down Glen Etive are usually intent on bagging the impressive Ben Starav.With every car park along the A through Glen Coe full to overflowing I decided I wanted a quiet day on the hill. I knew from past experience on Beinn Maol Chaluim that I neednrsquot go far in search of it.Glen Etive, unusually, was also busy but with paddlers not hillwalkers. Every little waterfall had half a dozen stubby, brightly coloured canoes waiting to take the plunge and the grass verges were full of cars and people camping for the Easter weekend. Despite the general air of busyness I was still confident of a quiet day on Beinn Maol Chaluim.A large herd of red deer grazed close to the road as I parked the car just past Inbhir-fhaolain opposite the wind-ruffled waters of Lochan Urr. I momentarily thought of dropping down from the road to the lochside to take a photograph of the twin Buachailles of Glen Etive with the loch as a foreground but being an extremely lazy photographer decided, conveniently, that the light was too flat.And it was. Dark clouds just tickled the summits of the highest peaks and it felt unseasonably cold. There was a greyness in the day that suggested that winter hadnrsquot quite yet finished with us.Despite the chill it didnrsquot take long to get sweating on the lower slopes of Creag na Caillich, en route to Beinn Maol Chaluimrsquos southern ridge.The slope is unrelentingly steep but the upside is that you can gain height quickly and within  minutes or so I was getting a hint of what the views were to be like later in the day. The twin Buachailles looked magnicent and behind me the steep slopes of Stob Dubh fell into the glen in one scree-scarred curtain. Further down the glen I caught the silver sparkle of Loch Etive, trapped in the cleft between triple-topped Ben Starav and Beinn Trilleachean. Once you reach the broad south ridge of Beinn Maol Chaluim only a steep, short and sharp climb separates you from the magnicent high level ridge that leads to the summit. Although steep, itrsquos straightforward enough until you reach the top of it.There, the summit ridge is protected by a long wall of vertical red porphyry. You can avoid these crags by traversing right for some distance but there are one or two breaches in the wall where even non-scramblers can clamber through.Beyond it some minor tops lead to the summit ridge itself, which is pleasantly narrow and today, was fringed with snow.What a marvellous high-level romp this produces ndash on one side steep slopes lead to another ridge that connects with the Munro of Sgorr na h-Ulaidh and on the other side even steeper slopes drop down into the bare fastness of Gleann Fhaolain, the narrow glen that separates Beinn Maol Chaluim from the Bidean nam Bian mass.I had harboured tentative thoughts about descending into Gleann Fhaolain, climbing steeply to Bidean, following its ridge east to Stob Coire Sgreamhach before descending back into Glen Etive, but dark clouds obscured Bidean and there appeared to be a dusting of new snow on the higher tops. Discretion being the better part of valourI loitered for a while beside the two summit cairns, dropped down out of the wind for a scenic lunch break, then ed to Glen Etive the way I had come.As a reward the sun shone for a while on the descent, illuminating some of the finest views yoursquoll see in this magnicently mountainous part of highland Scotland. And was the hill as quiet as I expected  No, not quite. I saw three other people. Not bad for Easter weekend.CAMERON MCNEISHROUTE PLANNERMap: OS Landranger sheets and  Distance: About  miles kmTime: - hoursStart Finish: Glen Etive road Route: Leave the road and climb steep and grassy slopes W of the forest plantation. Pass some rocky outcrops on the left to reach the S ridge of Beinn Moal Chaluim. Continue N on the ridge and climb steeply to where some steep crags appear to bar further progress. Scramble over the crags or avoid them by traversing to the right. Cross a couple of subsidiary tops before you reach the long summit ridge. Follow this to the summit, which lies at the N end of the ridge. Return the same way.Due to restrictions, we are running our favourite previously ublished walks.
