story: Itrsquos a question that the Provost of Falkirk, Billy Buchanan, pictured right, has repeatedly asked of prime ministers and governments. It doesnrsquot seem such a silly question now that the former US president Barack Obama has confirmed that he has seen footage and records of unexplainable aerial phenomena apparently rewriting the laws of physics.He told CBS TV about these objects that ldquowe donrsquot know exactly what they are, we canrsquot explain how they moved, their trajectory. They did not have an easily explainable pattern. And so, you know, I think that people still take seriously trying to investigate and figure out what that is.The renewed interest in UFOs and aliens comes just days before the US defence and intelligence agencies are due to deliver a report on these mysterious sightings. It is likely to grudgingly admit to the possibility that we have been visited by extraterrestrials. It will be published at the beginning of next month and while it is likely to be hedged with caveats and doubts, itrsquos likely to conclude that intelligent beings with transportation far in advance of our own canrsquot be ruled out.The report was instigated by the Florida Republican senator Marco Rubio when he was acting Senate intelligence committee chair last year. He asked the then-director of national intelligence and the Secretary of Defense to provide an unclassied report by next month.ldquoAnything that enters an airspace thatrsquos not supposed to be there is a threat, Rubio said.In January, a website that archives declassied government documents, the Black Vault, published thousands of declassied CIA documents on UFOs.In August last year, the Pentagon resurrected a programme to collect and analyse information on mystery objects, and encouraged military members to report strange encounters to the task force.Luis Elizondo was part of the Pentagonrsquos earlier version of this group, the Advanced Aerospace Threat Identication Program , from  to .He told the US programme  Minutes that while there were simple explanations for some sightings, others were inexplicable and baffled physics. ldquoIs it some sort of new type of cruise missile technology that China has developed  h asked.Elizondo added: ldquoIs it some sort of high-altitude balloon thatrsquos conducting reconnaissance  Ultimately when you have exhausted all those what s and yoursquore still left with the fact that this is in our airspace and itrsquos real, thatrsquos when it becomes compelling, and thatrsquos when it becomes problematic.And in March, John Ratclfe, Donald Trumprsquos former intelligence director, said the forthcoming report would reveal there have been ldquoa lot more sightings of UFOs than have been made public.Falkirk TriangleTHERE could hardly be more sightings than in the so-called Falkirk Triangle, which stretches from the small town of Bonnybridge, where Buchanan is a councillor, east to Fe and then back to Stirling. There are about  sightings a year which,you are a cynic, almost amounts to mass hysteria.The first sighting was in  when a local businessman called James Walker was driving from Falkirk to Bonnybridge. He pulled up his car as a bright, star-shaped obstacle was blocking his path, hovering over the road, before it shot off at incredible speed. Others have claimed to have been kidnapped and examined by aliens before being ed. But why Bonnybridge  Is it some interstellar interchange, or is the Falkirk Triangle a window into another dimension Given the number of craft spotted, the council should impose some kind of congestion charge, although enforcement might be problematic.Allegations of kidnapping by aliens are not so unusual. In , the writer Michael Shermer, who wrote the Skeptic column for Scientic American and was no ufologist, was cycling along a lonely rural road in Nebraska.He describes what happened: ldquoA large craft with bright lights overtook me and forced me to the side of the road.ldquoAlien beings exited the craft and abducted me for  minutes, after which time I found myself back on the road with no memory of what transpired inside the ship. I can prove that this happened because I recounted it to a film crew shortly afterward.He had been cycling for  straight hours, , miles in the opening days of the ,-mile nonstop transcontinental Race Across America. He was exhausted and when his support crew in a motor home flashed lights and him urging him to take a break, in a hallucinogenic state they became transformed into aliens, in which memories of the s television series The Invaders were incorporated into his waking dream.ldquoBut at the time the experience was real, and thatrsquos the point. The human capacity for self-delusion is boundless, and the effects of belief are overpowering, he said.Numerous theoriesThis does not explain how two people could hold the same imagined abduction, like Garry Wood and his friend Colin Wright who were driving along the A between Edinburgh and Tarbrax in .The journey should have taken  minutes ndash but they turned up an hour-and-a-half late. Under hypnosis, Wood recalled being scooped up into disc-shaped craft and examined by a ft-plus alien with a large head and dark eyes with a long, slender neck, very slim shoulders and waist. A hoax  A far-fetched excuse It certainly canrsquot explain footage, taken by civil aircraft and the military, of objects in the sky travelling at speeds unattainable by earthly machines, or hand-break turning in the sky defying the laws of physics.In a laboratory at Glasgow University, Professor LeroyCronin and his colleagues have come up with a new theory ndash that the study of complex molecules holds the secret to discovering aliens. In a paper published this month in Nature Communications, he and his team describe their ldquoassembly theory, a new way of quantying molecular complexity, which can be used to determinea molecule required a biological system to create it.He said: ldquoItrsquos based on the idea that only living systems can produce complex molecules that could not form randomly in any abundance. This allows us to sidestep the problem of defining le ndash instead we focus on the complexity of the chemistry.In tandem with Nasa, the Glasgow team is trying to make new le detection instruments which could be sent on missions to discover alien le. They could kick off in Bonnybridge!They point out that assembly theory ldquorelies on molecular complexity alone, the le detection process is agnostic, with no assumptions that alien le will be chemically similar to le on Earth.As Mr Spock almost said: ldquoItrsquos le Jim, but not as we know it.Perhaps we will know more when the US report is published.

title: scotlands-greatest-historian-explains-exactly-union-peril
story: Scotland’s greatest historian explains exactly why the union is in periletmMillennium MemoriesSCOTLAND is at an historic crossroads. Therersquos a Holyrood mandate for a second referendum, facing an absolute lsquoNorsquo from Westminster. In the eyes of Scotlandrsquos most renowned historian, Sir Tom Devine, the union hasnrsquot been under such strain since the Jacobite risings were crushed.In a bid to unravel where Scotland now stands, in terms of the history of the union, the Herald on Sunday sat down with Professor Devine. Over two hours of conversation, the worldrsquos leading authority on Scottish history gave what amounts to a personal lecture for Herald on Sunday readers.BIRTH PAINSldquoLetrsquos start at the beginning, Devine says, ldquoin . The treaty was a union of partnership - thatrsquos very relevant to whatrsquos happening today.However, for the first  years ldquothere was no certainty that it would prevail in terms of a stable relationship. Aside from Jacobitism, there were two big problems: increased taxation due to Englandrsquos wars with France, and the ldquoviolation of the treaty by the Patronage Act of  which interfered with the way the church was run. Both fomented early tension and ldquohostility.Of course the main threat was ldquoJacobitism, the attempt by some elements of Scottish society to reverse the revolution of  [when the Catholic Stuart king, James II, was overthrown by Protestant William of Orange] and restore the Stuart dynasty.Although the Jacobites are remembered mostly for opposition to the Hanoverian regime, there was also, says Devine, a strong degree of ldquodisaffection from the union. Both matters were the cause of four ldquovery serious risings between  and the most famous of all .:Opinion: Throughout the pandemic Boris Johnson has had to battle with himselfMONEY, MONEY, MONEYAnti-unionism was driven mostly by economics. ldquoOne of the prime arguments made by those propagandising before the union was that it would bring bounty, says Devine. Scotland was promised ldquoan economic miracle, and after famine in the s and the financial disaster of the failed Darien expedition to establish a Scottish colony in Panama the idea of union with England ldquowas a powerful argument. You may be giving up your sovereignty but yoursquore getting economic goodies.However, the economic miracle didnrsquot happen. Scotland simply ldquodidnrsquot have the capacity to take advantage of the opportunities offered by union because the country wasnrsquot yet mature enough in material terms to exploit it.Both Jacobitism, and general dissatisfaction with the union, were partly driven by ldquoa revolution of frustrated expectations. Devine says ldquothere were Jacobite banners not simply proclaiming the Stuart dynasty but saying no to the union. There were many elements in the army of Charles Edward Stuart [Bonnie Prince Charlie] at Culloden who were not only opposed to the Hanoverians but also the union.Northeast Scotland, parts of the Highlands and islands, and parts of the southwestern border were ldquounambiguously anti-union. Anti-unionism was also ldquocommonplace in Glasgow and Edinburgh. Clearly, the Act of Union wasnrsquot agreed by the Scottish people - the event took place in a ldquopre-democratic society.Taxation, English interference in the Kirk, and the failure of the economic miracle to materialise all added to the ldquoinevitable growing pains of a union between two ancient enemies. There were three parties in parliament - the Jacobite Cavaliers, the Court party representing the establishment pushing for union, and the anti-union Country party which was out of power. There was broad parliamentary consent for the economic parts of the treaty, but dissent on most other elements. Riots broke out in Edinburgh as ldquothe street sided with anti-unionists in parliament.WAR AND SECURITYFrance - Englandrsquos great rival for world domination - saw the union ldquobolstering the power of its enemy, as it closed a backdoor to England in future wars. England, meanwhile, saw union as a national security imperative, protecting its northern border. With England emboldened militarily through partnership with Scotland, the union ldquohastened the intensity of the long wars with France until Britain emerged victorious at the end of the Napoleonic Wars in .Therersquos lesson to be learned in  from the early days of union. Scotland wasnrsquot ldquoannexed by conquest like Wales and Ireland, says Devine. ldquoIt was a partnership agreement and that partnership agreement has now been lost, and lost very recently. David Cameronrsquos granting of a referendum was an example of that partnership operating - he was quick to acknowledge the right of Scots to determine their own future, unlike his successor in Downing Street today.Devine believes thata second referendum happens ldquothe core weakness for those who wish Scottish independence will be economics, the same way economics caused dficulties in the first half of the th century.Debates today about currency, trade with England and ldquowhat kind of advantages and disadvantages would flow economically from independence ldquoecho some of the issues swirling around in the late th and early th centuries.:Poll finds only one fth of English voters oppose Scottish independenceTHE RISINGSIronically, the Jacobite risings helped secure the union. With expectations disappointed over the promised economic miracle, the threat of a successful Jacobite rebellion, which would have heralded theof Catholicism, ldquodisciplined pro unionists who were fed up with the way the union was going. Those who had a tepid commitment to the union - and given the religious make-up of Scotland theyrsquod have iniably been Protestant - were forced to group together. Those who were becoming increasingly anxious that the union wasnrsquot delivering could never have sided with those trying to break the union as that would have legitimised the forces of Catholicism. If Jacobitism didnrsquot exist, the union may have been in greater danger.That split in Scotland has echoes today. In the early s, ldquoabout a third of the population was probably anti-union. Today, Devine notes, itrsquos about -. Fear over isions, he says, will play a part in any future referendum, with unionists warning that ldquosuch a bitterly ided country is no basis for building a new nationYes won.The shaky early history of the union quickly changed, though, after the risings. By the mid th century, says Devine, ldquothe union was entirely unproblematic. How did such a sundered country unite so quickly Jacobitsim was ldquorooted out to such an extent by military and legislative means that it never recovered. By the late th century ldquoitrsquos become part of history. Jacobitism became sentimentalised in songs and Walter Scott novels. ldquoThat sentimentalisation, says Devine, ldquois the clearest example that it was beaten. If it had remained dangerous that sentimentalisation wouldnrsquot have occurred.BOOM TIMEHighland culture and power was also crushed, most famously in the Clearances. The Highland warrior was coopted into the British army, becoming a fabled part of empire after Waterloo.More importantly, though, than this pacication of the Highlands and destruction of Jacobitism was money. Scotlandrsquos ldquogreat lt off began. The country started industrialising at a remarkable rate. There was also a revolution in agriculture and mass urbanisation. ldquoThe material benefits promised by union began arriving in spades, says Devine. ldquoScotland began to feel at ease in the union.Scotlandrsquos economic revolution ldquowas the fastest and most decisive in Europe. Englandrsquos industrialisation built up over time, while in Scotland therersquod been ldquohardly any change until the mid th century when the economy exploded. ldquoThere was nothing like it in Europe until forced industrialisation in the Soviet Union, Devine said.It was this growth of wealth and industry which helped settle Scotland firmly into union. ldquoIt draws the poison of disaffection, Devine says. This accommodation with union was ldquoso complete by the s that some Scottish intellectuals feared total anglicisation, Devine explains. ldquoThere was a fear that the battle for economic development had been won at the cost of Scotlandrsquos identity.But lsquoScottishnessrsquo wasnrsquot destroyed, Devine says. Therersquos no ldquovictory of Britishness over Scottishness, rather a ldquohybrid identity of Britishness and Scottishness emerges.EMPIRE BUILDINGPatriotism remained, but Scotland was ldquothe most unnationalistic country in the world. While the great empires of Europe fell apart, Scotland ldquowas congratulating itself on being part of the British empire. The nation fully embraced the business of empire and colonialism.Another historical irony was that come the mid-th century, when Scotland was so thoroughly part of empire and union, there was almost a sense of ldquosemi-independence in terms of how the country was governed. Clearly, Westminster was sovereign, says Devine, but there was a tradition in parliament that Scottish MPs decided the ldquorelevant bills for the country - theyrsquod be put before parliament and hardly ever opposed. Scotland was also governed on a daily basis by lsquoScots in Scotlandrsquo when it came to the law, religion, education, hospitals, poor laws, and prisons.ldquoEngland was prepared to be tolerant, to stand back. There was no friction between the two countries because of Englandrsquos restraint. England refused to occupy more than its share of the marital bed.Another ldquodelicious historical irony, says Devine, is that now ldquothe situation is reverse hellipyou compare the mid-th century to Boris Johnsonrsquos union today there was arguably more Scottish control of its own business, apart from issues like macro economic policy, foreign policy and making war.ldquoAnother paradox, says Devine, is that with Scotland today ldquobeholden to England because of the Barnett formula it now experiences increased interference. The classic example is Brexit. It was the reverse of the kind of government that existed between England and Scotland in the th century because it exemplies, more than anything  in the entire history of the union, England using its weight and power to force through a decision overwhelmingly opposed by Scotland.VICTORIAN VALUESUnionism in the Victorian era was ldquobenign. The state wasnrsquot interventionist, and with no security threat from Scotland, England ldquodidnrsquot really care too much about what was going on north of the border.Against this backdrop, Scotland and England began the business of empire building as a ldquojoint partnership. Devine says: ldquoThe old aphorism is true: England ruled the empire and Scotland ran it hellip the two countries were bound in that imperial project. These bonds deepened in the th centuryrsquos two world wars which ldquobound the countries together in blood.The period throughout most of the th century until the collapse of the British empire after the Second World War was the high point of union, when ideas of SNP nationalism belonged to a ldquofringe sect.The end of empire signalled that ldquoBritain was no longer great, and was followed by a ldquoseries of economic catastrophes like the crises of the s which paved the way for Margaret Thatcher, and policies which ldquoalienated Scotland.Scotlandrsquos iconic industries collapsed - coal, steel, shipbuilding. For Scotland, trade with the empire was replaced by trade with England. Devine says hersquos more skeptical than most historians about linking the end of empire to the growth of nationalism - symbolised by Winnie Ewingrsquos  Hamilton by-election win - but the events of the latter half of the th century certainly created a sense ldquoof introspection in Scotland, the sense that a more ldquoScottish centred future was needed, fuelled in part by concerns over the increasing importance, and dominance, of the economic relationship with England.SNP ASCENDANTHowever, the rise of the SNP still ldquowasnrsquot inevitable. Things changed when Tony Blairrsquos Labour administration created the Scottish parliament. The idea that rather than ldquokilling off nationalism, Labour actually built its own gallows in Scotland through devolution is ldquovery pertinent, says Devine.At the same time, identity politics was on the rise and many were growing disenchanted with globalisation. ldquoThatrsquos a very important factor stoking nationalism, says Devine. People were becoming uneasy with the power of the large state. ldquoThey wanted more control, he says. This also played into growing criticism of the EU culminating in England quitting Europe.More importantly, though, was ldquothe apparent inability of successive British governments to cure Scotlandrsquos economic problems. Another irony, however, is that while economic discontent ran alongside the growth in nationalism, once the painful transformation of the s and s was over, Scotlandrsquos economy today has emerged in better shape than itrsquos been for a long time, says Devine.Once the SNP won its  majority, the path was laid for a referendum. Devine says the fact that support for Yes hasnrsquot disintegrated is crucial. ldquoIf there was another referendum the chances of Yes winning are now much greater.TORY DISRESPECTHowever, the other crucial factor is that the Tory Party today is ldquounlike any British government since the early th century. After breaking Labourrsquos Red Wall, itrsquos almost ldquohegemonic.Therersquos been a ldquoshattering effect on many Scots who ldquodidnrsquot want to leave their friends behind in Tory dominated Englandthey went down the independence road, says Devine. With the Tories seemingly unassailable ldquothatrsquos now changed.The most important historic change of all, though, is the attitude of the Tories in government. ldquoSince the early th century therersquos been no instance of such a brazen refusal to accept Scottish opinion as Brexit. Judged in the long history of the union, this is an extraordinary volte face. The word lsquodisrespectrsquo isnrsquot strong enough.Devine added: ldquoWhatrsquos preserved the union has been good management by England - as the dominant party. It was a policy of respect and restraint by the big elephant in the bed. Scotland is now in danger of getting pushed out of bed. The future is not my period, butindependence does come then the killer of union will be more England not Scotland, because of the abandonment of that system of restraint, partnership and respect.He added: ldquoThe governing party in England is a dferent Tory party to even the Thatcher years. Itrsquos much more right-wing. Something has happened which never existed until after : the rapid growth of English nationalism. He points to polls showing a majority of Tories happy to see the union crumble to save Brexit.ldquoThe Conservative party, which was the classic defender of union throughout its existence, can no longer be trusted to preserve the union because of the growth of this Little Englandism. Many of its supporters see Scotland as an ungrateful liability as they assume theyrsquore giving privileges out of their taxes to the Scottish people.ldquoThe union is undeniably in more jeopardy than it has ever been since the end of the th century. The vice the union is caught up in threatens to crush it - on the one hand therersquos the old enemy of Scottish nationalism, on the other therersquos the new enemy of English nationalism.THE FUTURERegardless of Tory mistreatment, the independence case is far from won. Devine says the SNPrsquos ldquoAchilles Heel is its failure to make a convincing economic argument. ldquoThe majority of sensible Scots are waiting to seethe SNP has real economic plans. They need to be totally honest with the electorate. Without the economic case being made itrsquos impossible to say whether ldquothe hammer of blow of Brexit and other aspects of UK government policy would lead to a Yes win.ldquoPeople accept the first few years of a post-union Scotland could be tough, but they may be willing to give the benefit of the doubt and vote for independencetheyrsquore told clearly and honestly what the challenges may be. If the SNP was willing to do that theyrsquod gain respect, Devine says.Devine believes any violence linked to the constitution is currently ldquomost unlikely. The SNP is law-abiding. ldquoScotland isnrsquot Catalonia. However, itrsquos ldquomore dficult to predict what might happen hellip from any extreme [unionist] elementsYes won. Even then it would be ldquosmall scale hellip hooliganism not a real ldquopolitical threat.Given the changed political landscape in England, Devine worries that any future negotiations - over the shape of a second referendum or the terms of separation - ldquowouldnrsquot be benign. London would undoubtedly play hardball. Any negotiations would be pretty brutal.He adds: ldquoIf Yes had won in  negotiations would have been relatively friendly as it was in the interests of both nations. I donrsquot think the English people at the moment are in the mood for that - and the Tory supporting majority certainly arenrsquot.

title: senior-snp-mp-admits-losing-second-referendum-mean-chance-independence-gone
story: With some Nationalists like Alex Salmond pushing for another vote as soon as possible, the veteran backbencher urged caution, noting how his biggest fear was that the pro-independence cause in Scotland would go the same way of that in Quebecdefeated in a second poll it would fizzle out.:Opinion: Throughout the pandemic Boris Johnson has had to battle with himselfldquoThat is the risk, declared Mr Wishart. ldquoFor me, the important thing is winning and you win when you feel you are in the best situation to enter the ring and deliver that knockout blow. You donrsquot go in when you are at % in the opinion polls and looking certain to be defeated.ldquoBecause of my studies of Canada and whatrsquos happened there, therersquos a high riska second independence referendum is lost, that is a once-in-a-generation[event] because it will be so hard to get the forces back together. There will be a huge depression that will settle on the whole movement and it will be hard to get that energy back again.ldquoWe will have lost the political momentum that has taken  to  years to build, he explained.In an exclusive interview for The Herald, the MP for Perth and North Perthshire, who chairs the Commons Scottish Affairs Committee, also said:*there was a ldquogood to reasonable chance Boris Johnson would, after all, agree to another referendum in  along the lines of the  Edinburgh Agreement because a refusal to do so would simply increase support for independence in Scotland*denying Holyroodrsquos mandate for Indyref or trying to put Scotland in a ldquolegal cage over constitutional arguments would not work as the issue of the Tory administration governing Scotland ldquowithout democratic legitimacy was ldquonever going to go away*the Tory suggestion that Indyref should be denied because of Nicola Sturgeonrsquos ldquorhetorical flourish ndash that the  referendum was a once-in-a-generation event ndash was ldquoabundantly absurd and*Mr Salmond was now a ldquomassive hindrance to the independence cause and the Alba party was an ldquoabsolute menace to the Yes campaign, being made up of the ldquoworst kind of social conservatives.Sitting in Westminsterrsquos airy, modern annexe of Portcullis House, Mr Wishart is on the verge of a landmark event. In two weeksrsquo time, he marks  years as an MP he officially becomes a parliamentary veteran.Yet he bristled at the suggestion he had become part of the Westminster Establishment given he is on the House of Commons Commission, that manages the parliamentary estate, and in  threw his hat in the ring to become John Bercowrsquos successor as Commons Speaker.ldquoPeople did suggest I might wear a full-bottomed wig but my candidacy was just a very humorous attempt to use it as a means of drawing attention to a few issues, the former Runrig musician explained.ldquoI never thought for a minute I would end up spending  years in this place. I thought one or two terms and I would go back and do something much more interesting and exciting in the world of music. Am I part of the Westminster Establishment  Absolutely and utterly not.Mr Wishart has now been chairman of the Scottish Affairs Committee for six years and is currently overseeing seven inquiries, covering such erse topics as welfare, Covid and the Union.With Conservatives having the largest number of committee members due to their election victory, the Perth MP said he had to be careful about chairing it. ldquoI pride myself on the fact we are able to have reports agreed almost unanimously.He claimed his Labour predecessor, Ian Davidson, ldquoused the committee as a sort of extra arm of the Better Together campaign some of the reports he produced were just outrageous.However, Mr Wishart has been accused by his opponents of similar tactics in furtherance of the independence cause.Last week, he got caught up in a stooshie with Douglas Ross, the Scottish Conservative leader, who accused him of ldquopoor and inept chairmanship after he quizzed Alister Jack, the Scottish Secretary, over Indyref.:Scotlandrsquos greatest historian explains exactly why the union is in perilldquoAll I did was ask what most of Scotland wanted me to ask. Irsquoll leave Douglas to answer for himself about how he behaved in the committee and whether he thought it was appropriate.As the pandemic recedes and the constitutional drumbeat gets louder, Mr Wishart accepted it was a ldquoreasonable assessment to suggest  would be the year when battle proper would be joined on Indyref.At present, he claimed the Tory leadership in London was acting ldquolike a bunch of headless chickens, setting its face against Indyref but there were ldquosome clearer and more informed voices within Conservative ranks, who knew the constitutional issue had to be dealt with or  they would drive ldquodemand for Scottish independence sky-high.ldquoThe Tories have to start thinking of how they will win this. Itrsquos something that is not going to go away. At some point, they are going to have to deal with this.Mr Wishart accepted Mr Johnson, by dint of the Toriesrsquo  manesto and subsequent General Election victory, had a ldquoUK mandate to refuse to facilitate Indyref but explained: ldquoThis is about legitimacy and democratic principles. He didnrsquot get a majority in Scotland and lost half his MPs in . Wersquove also had another electoral event with the Scottish elections since then[with] a clear democratic mandate for a Scottish independence referendum thatrsquos backed by democratic force and legitimacy.ldquoThese are the things Conservatives have to wrestle with just now. At some point, they are going to have to decide they are going to have to engage to resolve this or it just gets worse and worse for them.Mr Wishart, who shadows Commons Leader Jacob Rees-Mogg for the SNP, suggested Mr Johnson would legally challenge the promised attempt by the Scottish Government to hold its own referendum and the matter would probably end up in the UK Supreme Court.Butthe PM won, as many believe, what then  ldquoIt becomes messy, unprecedented and will lead to a constitutional, democratic crisis this country has never had before. Why on earth would you want to get into territory like that, when there is a simple way to resolve this Yet while the pro-independence forces saw a string of opinion polls give them the lead, of the last  snapshots only one has put the Yes campaign ahead. Has the SNP peaked The Nationalist grandee suggested the Salmond trial had had a negative impact on SNP support but as the memory of that controversy receded he had ldquoabsolutely no doubt whatsoever we will start to see support for Scottish independence continuing to rise over the next few months.While he exuded confidence Scots would opt for a future Scotland outwith the UK, Mr Wishart also warned of the consequences of a second referendum defeat.ldquoIf we lost again, we would be into some really tricky territory for us as a party, admitted the -year-old politician.ldquoWhat we observed after the second Canadian referendum[in ], which was lost by less than one per cent, is that any desire for another one collapsed in the Parti Quebecois and the forces of independence have now completely gone.He noted how, unlike in Scotland, the independence enthusiasts were of the older generation.ldquoThe curious thing about Canada, I found out when I was there just before lockdown kicked in, is the Parti Quebecois and the parties of independence in Canada are inhabited by people of my generation, who hark back to the referendum days. Young people are fed up with it and support a united Canada. Itrsquos so dferent from Scotland.ldquoAfter they lost the second referendum, the young people in Canada felt it wasnrsquot something they could invest in and it was an idea whose time had been and gone.Askedthat could that happen in ScotlandIndyref was mistimed and resulted in another defeat for the Yes campaign, Mr Wishart paused and replied: ldquoI fear that.ldquoThis is why I am one of those people who believe we only have an independence referendum when there is a very, very good chance we will win it because I sensewe lose another independence referendum the opportunity to become an independent nation will be more or less lost not because people wouldnrsquot have the right to bring forward their enthusiasm but they will just think ndash thatrsquos it.

title: recipes-past-recreated-new-exhibition
story: While a strong stomach might be required to handle the thought of hedgehog washed down with donkey tea perhaps just as well the Edinburgh diners of days gone by had a city packed with taverns to visit for a pot of low alcohol small ale to slosh it all down with.Or,a night in was more to their taste, a glass of wine laced with a spoonful of sugar and spiceshellipThe unusual sounding dishes are now to feature in a sensory tour of Edinburghrsquos newly restored -year-old Royal Mile building, Gladstonersquos Land, giving visitors a flavour of the tastes and smells its long-gone residents would have lsquoenjoyedrsquo day in and day out.Spanning three floors of the building, the tour will rewind time to the th, th and early th centuries to show how the cityrsquos trade and wealth, markets, cooking skills and kitchen equipment, influenced the kinds of dishes that would have been eaten by its occupants.While some dishes are familiar ndash such as porridge, oatcakes, mutton stews and oysters, which were consumed in huge quantities during the th and th century ndash others failed to stand the test of time.Few today, for example, might be tempted to sip from their china cups on black tea cut with sheeprsquos dung, a practice carried out in th century Edinburgh to eke out a little further the householdrsquos precious and expensive tea.While the tour delves into the lives and tastes of the tenementrsquos residents down the years, it also reflects events happening outside its towering walls, such as international trade which brought exotic spices and fruits to the city. For early residents of Gladstonersquos Land, no means to refrigerate or safely store raw meat and fish, and the backbreaking task of keeping fires going to cook and provide hot water, meant rustling up dinner would be a full time task that was fraught with danger.Lindsay Middleton, PhD researcher in food history at the University of Glasgow and University of Aberdeen, has been working with Gladstonersquos Land owners, the National Trust for Scotland, to create the tour.She says: ldquoHistorical food is something we are becoming increasingly interested in, whether it is history week on the Great British Bake Off or reading recipes in historical cookbooks and marvelling at strange ingredients and cooking techniques.ldquoUnlike French or Italian cuisine, Scottish food is not typically thought of as delicious or particularly ied. But Scottish food does have a rich and ied history.ldquoIn the harsh climate, Scottish people have had to be creative with food, leading to some historical dishes with excellent names, like rumbledethumps, a buttery mixture of potatoes and cabbage inky pinky, leftover roast beef cooked with carrots and gravy hodge podge, a stew of mutton and root vegetables.Meanwhile Scots, it seems have always been a sucker for something sweet: fairy butter, made from egg yolks, sugar and orange flower water, was a popular dessert sauce used to accompany biscuits and cakes.Hedgehog must have tasted better than it sounds: a dessert made with ground almonds, eggs, cream and butter, for some reason it was shaped to look like a hedgehog.The tour examines dishes down the centuries through the eyes of three women who lived at the tenement: Margaret Nobel, the we of a wealthy merchant who ran a high-end grocers and fabric business from the property in the th century, Elizabeth Pillans, an th century draper, and Mary Wilson who ran a boarding house at the location in the early th century.According to Lindsay, servants whose job it was to run Elizabethrsquos th century kitchen had their work cut out.ldquoIn the th century, the way that you would have cooked, illuminated and kept your house warm was by using fire. There is no oven here, only the kitchens of the very wealthy would have had these - having enough wood to keep an oven going was expensive, and ovens themselves took up a lot of space, as well as presenting a heightened fire risk.ldquoIt wasnrsquot until the th century that enclosed stoves and ranges were introduced into kitchens, so all cooking would have been done over an open fire.ldquoYou can imagine the amount of sweat, work and time that went into cooking a meal in the th century, she adds.Edinburghrsquos role as a bustling trade hub meant its better off citizens often had a first taste of exotic and unusual foods imported from across the world, while its narrow Old Town streets would be an aromatic mix of food, bodies and animals ndash alive and dead.ldquoThe smell of food, bodies and animals would have filled the messy and muddy streets, and it would have been incredibly noisy, she adds.ldquoFleshers, or butchers, would have the carcasses of cattle and sheep hanging up as they butchered them, blood joining the mud on the streets. Hucksters, who foraged for and sold shellfish from the nearby coast, would be gutting fish and shelling oysters on the street too.ldquoThere were also more expensive and exotic imported spices, wines and dried fruits.An inventory of Margaretrsquos husbandrsquos possessions in  showed a list of foods that would have been beyond the imagination of the cityrsquos poor, including raisins, ginger, sugar, pepper, cinnamon, nutmeg, rice, almonds, cloves, lemon-peel marmalade and tobacco were all listed.By the th century, Edinburgh was fascinated by tea, which would have been offered to customers of Elizabeth Pillansrsquo shop as they browsed her stock of satin, silks, lace, ribbons, furs and muslins.Some tea, however, left a bad taste: green tea would be coloured with dangerous chemicals such as copper carbonate or lead chromate to keep their colour, while black tea was laced with leaves, ash, floor sweepings, lead or sheep dung.Few who indulged in tea at the time, however, are likely to have paused to consider the tea and sugar came at the cost of enslaved lives.Visitors joining the tour will have the opportunity to sample some of Gladstonersquos Land favourites, such as donkey tea, a grim-sounding drink made from toast steeped in hot water until it took the colour and flavour of the bread. Sieved to remove the crumbs, it was then drunk.Rescued from demolition by the Trust in , over the last  years the building has mainly told the story of merchant Thomas lsquoGledstanesrsquo, who bought it in the early th century, and commissioned its Renaissance-style painted ceilings.Years of meticulous historical research has now uncovered the lives of other residents of the property.It has now reopened after a pound. million restoration, with three floors laid out to reflect the lives and employment of its occupants and the rise and decline of the cityrsquos Old Town told through interactive exhibits, documents and furnishings.Tables Through Time: Food in Gladstonersquos Land will begin next month.

title: ron-mckays-diary-forget-running-key-health-nice-hot-bath
story: The research was by Charles James Steward at Coventry University. He has a hot tub in his lab and invites volunteers to try it, wired up to ultrasound and heart monitors and technological gizmos beyond my understanding. An hourrsquos soak at  degrees produces the equivalent of a moderate jog, without the rain and the rabid dogs chasing you.Charlie also takes each volunteerrsquos temperature. The discouragement is that he uses a rectal thermometer.Apparently, a long-term study of Finlandrsquos sauna goers ndash therersquos almost one sauna per person there, three million in a population of five million, like Scotland but with birch twigs ndash discovered that four to seven sessions a week produced a  per cent reduction in the risk of fatal heart attacks. The same study showed that it also signicantly decreased dementia and Alzheimerrsquos disease.In other studies it was found that four weeks of regular sauna use improved blood pressure, exercise tolerance, fitness levels, and reduced hospital admissions. Daily hot tub therapy for three weeks was also shown to lower blood glucose levels in patients with type  diabetes. Phew.It gets even better. While sitting up to your shoulders in the hot tubat the constant temperature for  minutes is the ideal. A hot bath three times a week where the blood temperature is raised by just . degrees grows new blood vessels, increases insulin sensitivity , and results in improvements in fitness.Obviously you wonrsquot build up muscle lying in the bath or lounging in the sauna but while you canrsquot run a marathon from your hot tub the benefits of heat therapy seem indisputable.Crivvens! Free hot tubs for all on the NHS. It would be cheaper in the long run.End of peer showMy parliamentary petition to remove former BBC director-general Tony Hallrsquos peerage has hit the buffers. Hall, Baron Hall of Birkenhead, is the one who absolved Martin Bashir over his Diana interview and later, as director-general, waved through his rehire as religious editor.The rejection by the petitions team at Westminster points out that ldquothere are limited circumstances in which a member of the House of Lords can be expelled.Exactly. An act was passed in  which allowed, for the first time in history, expulsion from the unelected chamber.Prior to that members could only be suspended for non-attendance, or serving more than a one-year prison sentence, which was the only way to deal with the duffers then.No peer has been expelled. The nearest to it was in July  when Lord John Sewel, a former Labour councillor in Aberdeen, resigned after he was filmed by The Sun on Sunday allegedly snorting cocaine in his London flat while entertaining prostitutes. At least they werenrsquot flagellating him like the late Max Mosely.Hall has resigned as chair of the National Gallery but hersquos still able to turn up and collect his pound a day and vote on legislation. On Thursday, the North Antrim DUP Ian Paisley asked Commons Leader Jacob Rees-Mogg whether there was a mechanism that could be used to remove Lord Hallrsquos title and privileges following the scandal.In his response, Rees-Mogg said such mechanisms could be used but ldquothey are at the highest end of our constitutional activity for the most serious misdemeanours.So thatrsquos it. Lord Hall can keep his ermine. His reputation has long gone of course.Friends no moreThe one where I click the off switch. I didnrsquot watch Friends Reunited. I would only watch Friends in chains with my eyes glued open. A bunch of actors squeezing another buck out of a franchise is unseemly,common. The original was hackneyed, the characters were caricatures, the fake laughter was toe-curling, the bleached New York portrayed was like something out of a white eugenicistrsquos dream. But most of all it wasnrsquot funny.MacNamara banIn a range of towering peaks of revelation and vituperation in Dominic Cummingsrsquos parliamentary testimony, the Everest was surely recounting senior civil servant Helen MacNamararsquos reaction when she discovered that there was neither a ldquoPlan B on dealing with the pandemic nor a ldquoPlan A, nor indeed any cunning plan at all.As Cummings described it: ldquoHelen MacNamara said I have come here to the Prime Ministerrsquos office to tell you all I think we are absolutely f*****. I think this country is heading for a disaster. I think we are going to kill thousands of people. As soon as I have been told this I have come through to see you.MacNamara and Cummings were not close. As Deputy Cabinet Secretary, as well as the propriety and ethics enforcer, she had butted heads with Cummings over his treatment of civil servants. She also headed the inquiry into the allegations of bullying against Home Secretary Priti Patel and swerved Patelrsquos demand for a formal inquiry into who leaked the story to the media.Patel was ldquoconvicted of breaking the ministerial code but Boris Johnson rejected the verdict. As a result, his standards adviser Sir Alex Allan resigned last November.In January of this year, after leaks that she was to be moved sideways, she resigned. She is now number two at the Premier League, where she has stepped into another nest of hornets. She has neither confirmed nor denied Cummingsrsquos account. You can make of that what you want.Grand tourThe Giro DrsquoItalia finishes today. Arguably itrsquos an even harder race than the Tour de France but certainly the two are among the toughest sporting events in the world. The live Giro TV coverage doesnrsquot just show the interaction between teams and inidual riders, the spills, the hair-raising descents after almost perpendicular ascents, but also the magnicent and breathtaking Italian scenery. Itrsquos like a prolonged tourism promo, although itrsquos unfortunate that the take-up will be low because of the pandemic restrictions.Why canrsquot we do it here, a Tour de Scotland, showing off our own scenery and attracting thousands of tourists and spectators  Imagine the break or the peloton going up the Bealach-Na-Ba ndash .kms, % at its steepest ndash one of the most beautul routes in the world, before swooping down into Applecross  Or taking on Skye and the Cuillins  Itrsquos not asitrsquos a weather-dependent event. On two or three stages of the Giro some of the weather was so bad the cameras conked out and they also had to reschedule routes.Mairi Gougeon was appointed Tourism minister this month, and Maree Todd put in charge of sport. If they want me to plot the route Irsquom here.

title: tiny-fierce-coastal-wildflowers-defy-elements-focus-new-exhibition
story: Although lashed by wild winds and hammered by sea spray, they defy the elements to sprout from rough and rocky crevices and to carpet paths.Now, a new collaboration is highlighting the erse range of wildflowers that thrive across the Rhins of Galloway, so visitors can identy and appreciate the blooms, and better understand how they have managed to thrive in some of the toughest conditions.The wildflowers of the Rhins of Galloway clfs and coastline feature in a new exhibition hosted at Logan Botanic Garden, alongside its collection of plants and trees some of which - thanks to the impact of the warm Gulf Stream - are only found in that area of Scotland.The Logan exhibition complements a new guide to the arearsquos wildflowers, designed to help visitors drawn to the new Rhins of Galloway Coast Path become familiar with the most common species they are likely to encounter.The new pound. million Lottery-supported -mile path will create a spectacular route enabling walkers to travel seamlessly from the windswept clfs of the Mull of Galloway, the most southerly point in Scotland, to the sheltered waters of Loch Ryan.It will also link up with the existing Mull of Galloway trail to establish an -mile circular route. As well as spectacular clf and coast views, the path will take in Iron Age forts, the historic Corsewall Lighthouse on the northern coast of the Rhins of Galloway, views of Ailsa Craig and Arran, and the atmospheric Dunskey Castle at Portpatrick.Eventually itrsquos hoped the new Rhins of Galloway Coast Path will also link to a wider network of long-distance routes, including the Southern Upland Way and the Ayrshire Coastal Path.The Rhins of Galloway walking routes takes in locations where several species of wildflowers which reach the northern limits of their UK distribution can be found. In some cases, they are unlikely to be seen where in Scotland.However, the impact of climate change has raised questions over how well they and other small but hardy species of coastal flowers and plants will cope in the future.According to Richard Baines, Curator at Logan Botanic Garden, there is a chance that some coastal species may find themselves trapped. ldquoThe plants are moving in a more northerly direction because of climate change, he says. ldquoBut for plants on this south west coast there is the question of where do they go ldquoIn terms of bioersity, they are an intrinsic part of the food chain for surrounding insects and animals. Their root systems also help stabilize their home soil which helps prevent erosion - a particularly useful factor for the wildflowers at a coastal location such as The Rhins of Galloway Coast.Spotlighting  of the most common species, the wildflower guide which accompanies the exhibition shows visitors how to identy flowers like sea campion, with its sprawling grey leaves and delicate white flowers with a veined bladder which grows on clftops, rocky shores and shingle banks, and English stonecrop.Despite its name, the plant, with its white starry flowers on a matt of succulent leaves, is a common feature on the west coast of Scotland.Some wildflowers, such as golden samphire, which is identiable by its bright yellow daisy-like flower and fleshy stem, reach their northernmost range on the Rhins. The flowers can be found on clfs near the Mull of Galloway.While the likes of wild thyme will be more familiar to many, particularly as they stroll over coastal paths carpeted with its purple flowers and distinct aroma.Itrsquos hoped the exhibition and guide will spark fresh interest in coastal wildflowers and plants which once formed a key part of le in the area.ldquoThere is a whole range of coastal wildflowers that thrive along the Solway Coast, adds Richard. ldquoOver the years, people who lived in the area would have been familiar with the plants for medicines and culinary uses.ldquoThere are also lots of stories in the area related to witchcraft and the use of plants as cures for ailments.One commonly consumed around the coast was sea kale, with its fleshy root which contains more starch than potatoes.While Sea Pink, also called Sea thrt and identiable by its long stems and globes of bright pink flowers, was so commonly known across the country that it featured on the back of old threepenny coins.Some plants are tucked on precarious clfs, making them dangerous to even try to examine up close. However, others provide dazzling carpets of colour ndash sea squill produces vivid blue springtime flowers that blanket the clftops.The exhibition at Logan Botanic Garden, which has been developed alongside the Rhins of Galloway Coast Path Project, includes a photographic display highlighting some of the main species to be found on the route of the path.There are also plans for a programme of events which will offer visitors to the opportunities to find out more about the rich natural and cultural heritage of the Rhins of Galloway.The creation of the path, which is managed by Dumfries and Galloway Council, has been financially supported by the National Lottery Heritage Fund and Coastal Communities Fund.lsquoWildflowers of Coastal Clfsrsquo runs at Logan Botanic Garden in Port Logan, throughout June.

title: kevin-mckenna-dominic-cummings-testimony-shows-tory-dregs-risen-top
story: One of the most iniquitous aspects of Team UKrsquos increasingly desperate attempts to mitigate its early failures in responding to the health crisis was to roam the planet looking for pictures to show how thankful we should be.ldquoLook, we know a lot of you will emerge from the pandemic minus a granny or two but at least they werenrsquot lying in the streets begging for oxygen or getting taken to filthy wards on the backs of bicycles.The BBC, self-appointed captain of Team GB, has ceased to be a news-gathering operation during the last  months and become an emotional crutch.Announcements of mass job losses were accepted unquestioningly and footage of irresponsible northerners gathering on public transport and thronging beaches came with an unmistakeable patina of disdain. UK ministers queued to be interviewed on BBC Breakfast where a cuddle and a hot cup of tea awaited while the other side was boycotted for its disrespectful line of questioning.We were invited to recoil at how quickly the infrastructures of less civilised nations were crumbling.And yet, as Mr Cummings revealed in eye-watering detail on Wednesday, the UK Governmentrsquos critical response unit resembled feeding time at the zoo. Three months after initial reports of a lethal pandemic on the loose our Prime Minister was so dismissive of the threat he wanted to get publicly infected by it.Herd immunity, as Mr Cummings revealed, really was the chosen policy in those crucial early weeks, despite the fact that public health experts were all warning that pursuing this without a vaccine had never been used to deal with infectious diseases.The UK Government still insists it was only following the science. Perhaps they were, but they seem to have been using the Eric Morecambe approach: playing all the right notes but not necessarily in the right order.Devi Sridhar, chair of global public health at Edinburgh University, dismantled this approach yesterday. ldquoThe reliance on complex theoretical modelling over the principles of basic infectious disease prevention was a problem so was groupthink within Sage [Scientic Advisory Group for Emergencies]As Mr Cummings continued to take his flame-thrower to the administration hersquod helped into power you could predict the means by which his targets would defend themselves. This was all about revenge, they insisted. ldquoWe all knew he was a bit of an oddball, so really, therersquos nothing to see here.:Fidelma Cook: Scotland didnt vote for Johnson and Patel ndash so do something about itThat all of his conscripted detractors were only there because of Mr Cummingsrsquo dark genius seemed incidental. In the last five years this ldquooddball had orchestrated an unlikely Brexit triumph before securing a comfortable electoral majority for its chief proponents. His attention to detail and knack for reading the runes in places that had never previously registered on the Toriesrsquo collective SatNav have made this party virtually unassailable in England. Yet, within a year the people who benefited from his intellect and instincts are insisting hersquos an unreliable witness. Aye, right.Some of the Prime Ministerrsquos defenders compared his coronavirus ordeal to the challenge faced by Winston Churchill at the start of the Second World War. ldquoLook, the PMrsquos done well in the circumstances. This though, doesnrsquot bear much scrutiny either. Arguably, Britain, facing conquest, slaughter, and enslavement from the greatest military force since the Romans started the war from a much weaker position than the modern, affluent, technologically advanced state that had been given due warning about this pandemic.Of course, some things remain unchanged since . Britain is still run by a tiny, upper-class, elite drawn almost exclusively from a handful of select finishing schools and Oxfordrsquos aristocratic drinking-clubs. The problem in , though, is that in those sepia-remembered days  years ago at least it was an elite that included some quality.These people ndash the Hancocks the Williamsons the Rees-Moggs ndash are the dreck: only there because of their slavish devotion to Brexit. They have built a sordid little mafia industry on the side, ever eager to exploit the pandemic for their own personal enrichment.As Matt Hancock got into his ministerial car on Thursday morning, he was wearing a Union Jack face-mask, this being the establishmentrsquos chosen mot of defiance throughout the pandemic. Itrsquos deployed shamelessly to bend Englandrsquos working-class communities to their will while spinning lines about togetherness and remaining steadfast ndash just like Winston. Amidst it all, the royal family are expected to earn their keep.To carry it off they need the acquiescence of those in the Labour Party who have made their fortunes posing as champions of the people. What do you think that off-the-books meeting between Prince William and Gordon Brown was all about last week The Scottish Government may yet have its own questions to answer and not just those about its early strategy around care homes. Unlike Boris Johnson, our First Minister maintains closer control of those she permits to be inside her very small tent. You wonrsquot find any whistleblowers at Bute House. Yesterday, she consigned Glasgow to yet another week in punitive, Level Three lockdown restrictions. The city is home to some of the most intense concentrations of multi-deprivation in Europe, a critical factor in the stubbornly high case numbers.: Kevin McKenna: Cummings statements reveal Covid- response was shambolicGlaswegians will grumble, but continue to hunker down, trusting that Nicola Sturgeon is doing it for the best. This trust comes with a caveat though. For, when Holyrood seeks to plot Scotlandrsquos Covid recovery, at its heart there must be a preferential option for Glasgow. The metropolitan city-region of Glasgow accounts for almost a third of Scotlandrsquos population and these communities will be hit hardest by the job losses and leline service cuts to come.The physical and mental scarring theyrsquoll experience will deserve special attention. The Scottish Government could signal its commitment to addressing this by establishing a Minister for Glasgow with full cabinet responsibility. Scotlandrsquos largest and most important city has been under-represented in Government for many years, but now more than ever it needs the First Minister to prioritise its needs.

title: douglas-chapman-snp-national-treasurer-resigns
story: Douglas Chapman, the MP for Dunfermline and West Fe, announced he had resigned as national treasurer of the party on Saturday evening.Mr Chapman took over in the role last year.:Alex Salmond launches international chapter of Alba PartyOn Twitter, he said: ldquoDespite having a resounding mandate from members to introduce more transparency into the partyrsquos finances, I have not received the support or financial information to carry out the fiduciary duties of National Treasurer.ldquoRegretfully I have resigned with immediate effect.It is not clear what led to Mr Chapmanrsquos decision, but SNP business convener and fellow MP Kirsten Oswald said she ldquofundamentally disagrees with Mr Chapmanrsquos assessment.Also on Twitter, she said: ldquoI am disappointed by Douglasrsquo decision and, as business convener, fundamentally disagree with his assessment of the support and financial information available to him.ldquoHowever, I respect his decision, thank him for his contribution to the NECand whish him well.:UK Supreme Court sets date for hearing on Holyroods powersldquoSNP national treasurers have access to detailed financial information and report to the NEC on a monthly basis.The NEC can request any additional information it requires.ldquoThe SNPrsquos accounts are also independently audited, submitted to the Electoral Commission and published.

title: scots-green-capital-europe-revolution-blown-proportion
story: The Herald on Sunday can reveal that what was initially a taxpayer-backed poundm investment fund to finance the offshore wind sector turned to what one union official described as "a farce" with just poundm paid out to one company promising  jobs in six years. And pound.m of that had to be paid back the following year when it decided to exit the offshore wind sector.While the Scottish Government was predicting  years ago that there would be , Scottish jobs in theoffshore wind industry alone by  as the nation takes advantage of its benefits - the latest workforce data for  shows it stands at just .It comes as concerns persist over the continuing lsquomothballingrsquo of the UKrsquos only facility for manufacturing onshore and offshore wind towers in Machrihanish, Argyllshire, owned by South Korea-owned CS Wind UK.It comes six months after administrators were formally appointed to take control of part state-owned Burntisland Fabrications , the insolvent renewables manufacturer run from Canada seen as a key part of the future of Scotlands wind farm revolution.Deloitte took control of affairs of BiFab after it collapsed when the Scottish Government did a u-turn in backing the firm.Two of the three BiFab fabrication yards - Methil in Fe and Arnish on Lewis - have since been bought out of administration by London-based firm InfraStrata. The former BiFab fabrication yard at Burntisland in Fe was not part of the deal and has since sprung back to le under Forth Ports ownership, with Aberdeen-based e systems specialist Orca Oceanic Systems setting up an operations facility.Unite Scottish Secretary, Pat Rafferty who has been fighting for a fairer deal over green jobs said:"Itrsquos absolutely staggering that based on how the offshore wind sector is supposed to be the jewel in Scotlands renewables revolution that only  jobs were estimated to have been directly created in ."When you factor into that the dismal picture that the Scottish Government projected , jobs to have been created by now, and that only  more jobs have been created since  then you begin to appreciate the abject failure of government policy at the Scottish and UK level."CS Wind in Machrihanish, which manufactures onshore and offshore wind turbines has been mothballed by its Korean owners."And we also have had the well documented challenges facing the BiFab yards in Fe and Arnish.Ministers championed the desire for the nation to cash in on low carbon in  and  - saying Scotland can be the "green energy capital of Europe" with a workforce rising to , and offshore wind alone bringing in an estimated poundbn in inward investment.Office for National Statistics figures produced from a low carbon and renewable energy economy survey show that in Scotland there were just , jobs in the low carbon and renewable energy economy - including businesses specialising in offshore and onshore wind, hydropower, carbon capture, alternative fuels, energy efficient lighting, low emission vehicles.Twelve years ago, the potential wind and marine energy power in the Pentland Firth - where the north-east Atlantic meets the North Sea ndash led the then Scotlands First Minister Alex Salmond to dub it the "Saudi Arabia of Renewables" with BiFab at the time making turbines for offshore wind farms.In November, , First Minister Alex Salmond, first announced a poundm investment fund to finance the offshore wind sector.He said it could create up to , jobs and add pound. billion in value to Scotlands economy over  years.Two months earlier, he told financiers that innovation and advances in clean green energy present a "pivotal turning point in human history".Opening the Scottish Low Carbon Investment conference in Edinburgh, he urged private finance leaders to seize the multi-billion pound opportunities arising from the renewable and low carbon technology revolution.He unveiled an industry-led Offshore Wind Route Map, setting out the key actions required in the coming years to fully realise the huge potential around the coast of Scotland - estimated at that time to have a quarter of Europes potential offshore wind and tidal capacity and a tenth of its wave resource.He announced: "This is more than a once-in-a-generation opportunity such as North Sea Oil and Gas was."The Scottish Governments low carbon strategy published in  described the large scale development of offshore wind as representing the "biggest opportunity for sustainable economic growth in Scotland for a generation" with Scotland having an estimated % of Europes offshore wind potential.But the Herald on Sunday can reveal that the POWERS fund that was eventually launched in  and overseen by Scottish Enterprise for poundm, only awarded one poundm grant during its six years.Samsung Heavy Industries won the award in October,  towards the poundm capital cost of building their MW prototype turbine at Energy Park Fe.It was billed by Scottish Enterprise as the largest and most powerful offshore wind turbine who said it had the backing of Mr Salmond "whose government wants all Scotlands electricity to come from renewables by ".The Korean company was said to have invested poundmillion in the Fe wind turbine demonstrator scheme, and Scottish Enterprise said it had the potential to create up to  jobs in Scotland.Alex Salmond said of SHIs move to base its first European offshore wind project in Fe in an inward venture championed as worth up to poundm: "I am extremely pleased to welcome this inward investment by SHI which further reinforces Scotlands place in the development of the next generation of offshore wind turbines.ldquoTheir choice of Scotland as their first base in Europe for renewable technology development is testament to the fact this country is fast becoming the European centre for research and development in new offshore wind technologies."Insik Roh, chief executive of Samsung Heavy Industries, said at the time: "The testing of the new MW offshore wind turbine at the Fe Energy Park signies a milestone in the development of Samsungs new wind turbine generator system. We hope to contribute to the Scottish economy through successful testing and certication of our cutting edge offshore wind turbine and ultimately through establishment of our manufacturing facility here in Methil."Scottish Enterprise announced at the time: "SHI said that, following a successful testing period, it will work to attract orders for its turbines. This would allow it to build a world-class manufacturing facility at Energy Park Fe."SHI, which wants to become a leading player in the European offshore wind sector, has been manufacturing .MW wind turbines for four years and already has turbines installed in Korea, the US and Canada."It chose to base its European operation at Energy Park Fe because of the arearsquos growing energy cluster and the huge opportunities this presents for supply chain companies, particularly those involved in the offshore wind sector."But the  jobs did not materialise.Scottish Enterprise says that in late  the company took a "strategic decision" to exit the offshore wind sector and wind down its offshore wind business.The turbine was acquired by the Offshore Renewable Energy Catapult in  and rebranded the Levenmouth Demonstration Turbine. It currently employs five people.Scottish Enterprise said that pound.m of the poundm award was paid back saying: "It would have been as a result of Samsung not fully meeting the conditions of the funding." It did not know how many jobs had been created by existing turbine.Charles Thompson of Offshore Renewable Energy Catapult said: ldquoSince ORE Catapult acquired the Levenmouth turbine in , more than  small businesses have benefitted from its facilities and data to develop and demonstrate innovative products and services for the renewable energy market. It is a globally unique facility that directly helps Scottish businesses to grow in the fast-growing green energy industries."A Scottish Government spokesman said: ldquoWe are committed to supporting Scottish supply chain growth and to utilising every lever at our disposal to increase local content in offshore wind projects, and welcome the UK Governmentrsquos commitment to changes to the Contracts for Dference supply chain plan process. The introduction of Supply Chain Development Statements by Crown Estate Scotland, as part of the ScotWind leasing round, will help to release economic benefits for the Scottish economy and we expect developers to honour their commitments.ldquoThrough our poundm Green Jobs Fund and other mechanisms at our disposal, we will make investments to support Scotlands supply chain, empowering businesses and workers to take advantage of the opportunities arising from Scotlands just transition to net zero.

title: orkney-shetland-bute-benbecula-best-worst-scots-islands-rated-uk-travellers
story: The archipelago of over  islands and skerries, of which  are permanently inhabited, was rated number one in a survey involving over  people in the UK judging Scotlands islands in terms of hotel pricing, beaches, food and drink, accommodation, tourist attractions, scenery and shopping. They also rated islands on peace and quiet, ease of travel and value for money.While Scotlandrsquos waters are home to approximately  islands, the consumer organisation Which survey rated only .Which said that this highlighted how undiscovered and uninhabited many of them still are.And of the  that received enough visitors to be ranked in the survey,  received an impressive visitor score of  per cent or more.Many of Scotlandrsquos islands, including Orkney, are currently under Level  coronavirus restrictions, which means visitors can freely travel to the islands unless they are in Glasgow which is in Level , or under other tiered restrictions across the rest of the UK.Orkney took the top spot in the table with visitors awarding it a score of  per cent.The island was the only one in the survey to receive five stars for its tourist attractions, with visitors speaking highly of its many prehistoric sites and archaeology.:Scots communities go Nordic in rising demands for their own flagsSome of the most frequently cited highlights included the Italian Chapel and the stone-built Neolithic settlementSkara Brae. Also rated highly was the ldquospectacular Neolithic henge and stone circle Ring of Brodgar.The islands, ten miles of the coast of Caithness were also praised for their ldquobeautul scenery and friendly locals, while others cited its remoteness as its main attraction.One was particularly impressed by the ldquomiles and miles of secluded sandy beaches with no-one in sight".In second place was Shetland, with a score of  per cent.Of its  or so islands, only  are inhabited, which could go some way to explaining its five-star rating for peace and quiet.Which said: "This, combined with the fact it is closer to the Arctic Circle than it is to London, might lead some to think it could be dficult to reach ndash but the island was given four stars for ease of travel."The islands also received four stars for the scenery, tourist attractions and shopping, meaning most travellers will be well catered to.Harris, Islay and Mull each received a visitor score of  per cent, putting them in joint third place.Harris received five stars for both its beaches and its scenery, as well as for peace and quiet, with Which saying this makes making it the perfect destination for anyone looking to escape to the great outdoors.Islay, known for its distillery tours and whisky tasting, also received five stars for peace and quiet, as well as four stars for its food and drink.But Which says it is not just for its whisky though, with fishing another mainstay of the island, meaning visitors can enjoy fresh seafood or fish and chips from many of the islandrsquos restaurants.While Mull only scored three stars for tourist attractions, food and drink, and shopping, according to the survey, the main attraction was its five-star scenery, made up of white-sand bays fringed with wildflower-rich grassland, and pink granite skerries scattered across the sea.Only one island in the survey received a score that dipped below  per cent, which Which said was largely down to it being seen as a stepping stone between North and South Uist. Benbecula received a visitor score of  per cent, but still received four stars for its beaches and its peace and quiet.While it only received three stars for scenery, visitors still spoke warmly of its beaches and landscape, with its wildle and birdwatching being praised by a number of those in the survey.The Inner Hebrides island of Iona, famed for its abbey, which was a centre of Gaelic monasticism for three centuries, was the only island to get a one-star rating across the ten categories - for shopping.Rory Boland, Which travel editor said: ldquoAfter more than a year of restrictions that have seen most of us confined to our homes, many of us will be craving a holiday featuring beautul scenery, grand landscapes, and the peace and quiet to soak it all in. The Scottish islands have all of this in abundance, making many of them a brilliant choice for a UK holiday this summer.ldquoYoursquoll need to pack for all seasons, and be prepared for a bit of travelling to get there ndash but when you do, yoursquoll be glad you made the effort. Just be sure to book with an accommodation provider that will allow you to freely change or cancel your booking at short notice, should coronavirus restrictions change and prevent you from travelling as planned.Which advised that anyone planning to visit one of the islands should check the restrictions in place at the time they are due to travel, and only book with a provider that will allow them to rebook or cancel for a refundthey cannot travel as a result of government restrictions.The Scottish government is also encouraging anyone planning on travelling to one of Scotlands islands to take a coronavirus test before they do to reduce the risk of the virus being brought into island communities. Visitors are recommended to get tested three days before travelling and then again on the day of departure.
